5EBBDD0A9C954AEAB2432A93C0655C9E.description: explore and explain careers that involve astronomy, space exploration, and the technologies developed through them.

07046688B44F4AA09B1C56B9F6CF4C6B.description: examine and describe current developments and discoveries in astronomy; and

089A361396E0489F84AB321DD3B9B0CB.description: evaluate the impact on astronomy from light pollution, radio interference, and space debris;

D125D3379EB1407B8445A24EEA624C65.description: evaluate the evidence of the existence of habitable zones and potentially habitable planetary bodies in extrasolar planetary systems;

60E4AA8394F54BB49BBB8B1D4ADE34FE.description: describe and communicate the uses and challenges of robotic space flight;

B60B548665B94622BEEEF12DC068EE42.description: describe and communicate the historical development of human space flight and its challenges;

5B4F1CBCC95B4F69A53D5F7F5DF2A73A.description: Science concepts. The student understands the benefits and challenges of expanding our knowledge of the universe. The student is expected to:

7CC238E406764E40A68C5839286BB418.description: describe current scientific hypotheses about the fate of the universe, including open and closed universes.

1F277693EC9A476A8A5C9C5468539AE4.description: describe the current scientific understanding of the evolution of the universe, including estimates for the age of the universe; and

6E4153658880415188433D9A27ABA48A.description: evaluate the indirect evidence for the existence of dark energy;

60E97A34D1E3461CB4354E7F7A961142.description: evaluate the limits of observational astronomy methods used to formulate the distance ladder;

486EE69F73274E7CB3B41CAA616EF6FB.description: describe and evaluate the historical development of evidence supporting the Big Bang Theory;

10B2B891B27B48D9A75E9EE0A8E30ABD.description: Science concepts. The student knows the scientific theories of cosmology. The student is expected to:

D7C38445A9F24319B432DA40B69258BB.description: evaluate the indirect evidence for the existence of dark matter.

95C7FD6404D749DD9B31A0E5B8A06BE3.description: describe the Local Group and its relation to larger-scale structures in the universe; and

6DB1828CC2574DFDA5D36C820DC1B508.description: develop and use models to explain how galactic evolution occurs through mergers and collisions;

58411D43C0FE461EA90A0498D9FD6CC0.description: compare spiral, elliptical, irregular, dwarf, and active galaxies;

5D317CC24BD042A4AA2A1C86C06FDB67.description: illustrate the structure and components of our Milky Way galaxy and model the size, location, and movement of our solar system within it;

B9653A4BE52943AEA3DE86B01B4049F2.description: Science concepts. The student knows the structure of the universe and our relative place in it. The student is expected to:

2C986BF68ACD4869B6D88C739554E422.description: describe how stellar distances are determined by comparing apparent brightness and intrinsic luminosity when using spectroscopic parallax and the Leavitt relation for variable stars.

B266B8B04CF6408B95D8F9EF3595C085.description: illustrate how astronomers use geometric parallax to determine stellar distances and intrinsic luminosities; and

0B3140495AF34BD69AB8494EDD2D1BB4.description: use the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram to classify stars and plot and examine the life cycle of stars from birth to death;

3DD915BD9505492FA9E7A627A0DAADE0.description: describe the use of spectroscopy in obtaining physical data on celestial objects such as temperature, chemical composition, and relative motion;

39B121B509AC474E8CE9EDDD40A02E32.description: compare how the mass of a main sequence star will determine its end state as a white dwarf, neutron star, or black hole;

430A0B21F93E47D1B2F59C36F91693C3.description: evaluate the relationship between mass and fusion on stellar evolution;

9E0E9377C1A94E39A206234619A4F6CB.description: describe and communicate star formation from nebulae to protostars to the development of main sequence stars;

EF80DB467F50417EB754F245482D5DD5.description: identify the characteristics of main sequence stars, including surface temperature, age, relative size, and composition;

2469367F49234C24A8399716E841629B.description: Science concepts. The student understands the characteristics and life cycle of stars. The student is expected to:

27E1088D493C47CA9DD452A63C7CD43B.description: analyze the origins and effects of space weather, including the solar wind, coronal mass ejections, prominences, flares, and sunspots.

1BD7C7A35BB240A99574158FEAF51D6F.description: describe the eleven-year solar cycle and the significance of sunspots; and

1B29DAE5E05F4AB4ACED2F5143870373.description: distinguish between nuclear fusion and nuclear fission and identify the source of energy within the Sun as nuclear fusion of hydrogen to helium;

2A58B6A53FF649529CE01CDAAE8C1D53.description: identify the approximate mass, size, motion, temperature, structure, and composition of the Sun;

8F4E471E043A406AAD071A9E144CDCA1.description: Science concepts. The student knows that our Sun serves as a model for stellar activity. The student is expected to:

8A1B7F70373243CFA720F8E58213BD06.description: compare the factors essential to life on Earth such as temperature, water, gases, and gravitational and magnetic fields to conditions on other planets and their satellites.

F2AEC16AA99A4E578DE637021FFE89DB.description: compare the planets in terms of orbit, size, composition, rotation, atmosphere, natural satellites, magnetic fields, and geological activity; and

B68171DD3A884C6D85138E5DC0B41892.description: explore and communicate the origins and significance of planets, planetary rings, satellites, asteroids, comets, Oort cloud, and Kuiper belt objects;

B0E775D245664BB3ABA8B67AB66F1901.description: relate Newton's law of universal gravitation and Kepler's laws of planetary motion to the formation and motion of the planets and their satellites;

ECDD15876AB7400BB974AE70ADE723EE.description: Science concepts. The student uses models to explain the formation, development, organization, and significance of solar system bodies. The student is expected to:

5BD5D94264AD43FC93B6D15E9B9F110F.description: analyze the importance and limitations of space telescopes in the collection of astronomical data across the electromagnetic spectrum.

3892F762287A4F99A8E553DC6ECDBBD3.description: analyze the importance and limitations of optical, infrared, and radio telescopes, gravitational wave detectors, and other ground-based technology; and

DEFF8AAC422D437994AB7E289C4A3823.description: calculate the relative light-gathering power of different-sized telescopes to compare telescopes for different applications;

39F4CD908DCC491B9536E97AC54A7F83.description: investigate the use of black body radiation curves and emission, absorption, and continuous spectra in the identification and classification of celestial objects;

9F70D7AD851649769296E886887FAC9B.description: Science concepts. The student knows how astronomical tools collect and record information about celestial objects. The student is expected to:

E7709B284DE64E01A036850D33636587.description: explain the significance of Earth's solstices and equinoxes.

C7ABD45F614242F682DE9A450DA5A4A1.description: investigate the relationship between a planet's axial tilt, angle of incidence of sunlight, and concentration of solar energy; and

DF11C176D8944FE4A27B3E504CC039EB.description: predict how changing latitudinal position affects the length of day and night throughout a planet's orbital year;

883CCB65DF3342C88A266E3CCF35F496.description: examine the relationship of a planet's axial tilt to its potential seasons;

9C8B4827B155424893C3EB0131400D17.description: Science concepts. The student models the cause of planetary seasons. The student is expected to:

D93AD27FD5C1418995A57DF7B2D45EDB.description: examine and investigate the dynamics of tides using the Sun, Earth, and Moon model.

E8094581618240A08FD2D02D3ABC650E.description: model how the orbit and relative position of the Moon cause lunar and solar eclipses; and

380B2F424465486099631A711086E24F.description: model how the orbit and relative position of the Moon cause lunar phases and predict the timing of moonrise and moonset during each phase;

44F02486E7CB4A38A8939911F7E6B6F4.description: Science concepts. The student observes and models the interactions within the Sun, Earth, and Moon system. The student is expected to:

6FB192B5356C470BB693D9E348681618.description: model the scale, sizes, and distances of the Sun and the planets in our solar system and identify the limitations of physical models.

9154526C708A4053A4DC979056D32D56.description: model the scale, size, and distances of the Sun, Earth, and Moon system and identify the limitations of physical models; and

81F5C7ACD67C43549AE436EEA82ED097.description: demonstrate the use of units of measurement in astronomy, including astronomical units and light years, minutes, and seconds;

AEBDF48CB5EF4906A9551B10C5F43D35.description: Science concepts. The student knows our relative place in the solar system. The student is expected to:

BCBD9722014244819675421643598248.description: understand the difference between astronomy and astrology, the reasons for their historical conflation, and their eventual separation.

16C59B993C40480D85D3A331DA1B6A5B.description: identify constellations such as Ursa Major, Ursa Minor, Orion, Cassiopeia, and constellations along the ecliptic and describe their importance; and

3134036144FF44199C1BE9D817BFEE43.description: observe the movement of planets throughout the year and measure how their positions change relative to the constellations;

D0563C8209544F52AF4E160E6C65996D.description: observe, record, and analyze the apparent movement of the Sun, Moon, and stars and predict sunrise and sunset;

B76F06598DD74C68A6D78C6137EC0098.description: Science concepts. The student conducts and explains astronomical observations made from the point of reference of Earth. The student is expected to:

05C2B445F1FE4E34ADEE31D118AD3355.description: describe and explain the historical origins of the perceived patterns of constellations and the role of constellations in ancient and modern navigation.

B8EEA5AEAB5A4BABA9A49C519947DCD7.description: research and evaluate the contributions of scientists, including Ptolemy, Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Kepler, Galileo, and Newton, as astronomy progressed from a geocentric model to a heliocentric model; and

246EAA2E3EA845FFA8ADC5D406D5B786.description: evaluate and communicate how ancient civilizations developed models of the universe using astronomical structures, instruments, and tools such as the astrolabe, gnomons, and charts and how those models influenced society, time keeping, and navigation;

23A3C9A528C64C628B865861510EF969.description: Science concepts. The student understands how astronomy influenced and advanced civilizations. The student is expected to:

05E80E6B94D2482391B143FD1D9E354F.description: research and explore resources such as museums, planetariums, observatories, libraries, professional organizations, private companies, online platforms, and mentors employed in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field in order to investigate STEM careers.

ED3A7836447A4053958BA27242F48F18.description: relate the impact of past and current research on scientific thought and society, including research methodology, cost-benefit analysis, and contributions of diverse scientists as related to the content; and

FA47F75C45AE4D579978EDFA4C2A3B81.description: analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations and solutions by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

67594C6720CD47BF9A8E751737D75D8F.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student knows the contributions of scientists and recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected to:

4EAA79BB3878448C9F69A0D8376B1FCF.description: engage respectfully in scientific argumentation using applied scientific explanations and empirical evidence.

F6E7ABE587C84CCAA8E4FB169C2454C3.description: communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of settings and formats; and

15AB32D9C6074A07B5CCA308C901002E.description: develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models consistent with scientific ideas, principles, and theories;

C536D44C556F4B72A8C5C26C1CAD7CC2.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student develops evidence-based explanations and communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

45E63B6EDC884A7CBF0B0B0DA5DE87E6.description: use mathematical calculations to assess quantitative relationships in data; and

2179593CBC0945E38F6E0386900DF01D.description: analyze data by identifying significant statistical features, patterns, sources of error, and limitations;

DD9B685B7A544ED7B4203B68FDFB0737.description: identify advantages and limitations of models such as their size, scale, properties, and materials;

C010653ABD094F02BA8F3432614085D2.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning, identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

1DE33523A5E74516BD7B8DBA1234FF61.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses, theories, and laws.

B9FCB65A52F947EC8627B41B7ED17141.description: develop and use models to represent phenomena, systems, processes, or solutions to engineering problems; and

96B809571D3147F0B5BEAEFC86F18562.description: organize quantitative and qualitative data using graphs, charts, spreadsheets, and computer software;

43DBD8DBC71544F587F8AE5E2631AB09.description: collect quantitative data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative data as evidence;

CC849E26C6EC4D9F8E286FBD07060B30.description: use appropriate tools such as gnomons; sundials; Planisphere; star charts; globe of the Earth; diffraction gratings; spectroscopes; color filters; lenses of multiple focal lengths; concave, plane, and convex mirrors; binoculars; telescopes; celestial sphere; online astronomical databases; and online access to observatories;

57CCFA6CAB31446DB66A67F42132FEAC.description: use appropriate safety equipment and practices during laboratory, classroom, and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

8A753A05F1C9482AB3DE77570D5CA6C2.description: apply scientific practices to plan and conduct descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

90888566191448FB8CADE0DE8FD1CBF2.description: ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text, phenomena, models, or investigations;

BD371A2198394EAABEEF8B8F1573EB8D.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, asks questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field investigations to explain phenomena or design solutions using appropriate tools and models. The student is expected to:
